results.title: Wildlife
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Explains the need for conservation of wildlife in order to preserve the ecological balance of nature. Describes the endangered status of many species today, what has been done to control impending extinction in the past, and what can be done in the future through refuges. In collaboration with Allan A. Sollers, author of “Ours is the Earth”.
results.description:

results.title: Minerals
results.creator_credit: Bill Erwin, John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Introduces a variety of mineral resources vital to our present way of life. Emphasises that many of these resources are non-renewable and shows current efforts directed towards conserving mineral resources.

results.title: Forest and range
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Presents “multiple use programmes” in which American forests are used for produce in addition to recreation. This program juxtaposes the need for food, lumber and recreation against the desire to retain undeveloped areas.

results.title: Air
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Studies the affects of air pollution on health and property. Natural pollutants existed long before man but harmful pollution did not start until the start of the Industrial Revolutions. This film explains what has caused man-made pollution and what is being done to solve the problem through technological and legislative controls.

results.title: Using visual aids in training
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and United States. Office of Education. Division of Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in supervision”
An instructor, teaching his class the use of the micrometer, follows a carefully planned procedure involving the use of an instructional sound film, a film strip, and a study guide.

results.title: The Supervisor as a leader. Part 2
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker, Caravel Films and United States. Office of Education. Division of Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in supervision”
Four supervisors discuss the qualities of leadership with the assistance of dramatised incidents. One supervisor lets his job go to his head, while another goes to pieces under pressure. Emphasises that a good supervisor is not afraid to praise his colleagues for work well done and that he is loyal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: F.E. Brooker, Caravel Films and United States. Office of Education. Division of Visual Aids

results.title: The Supervisor as a leader. Part 1
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker, Caravel Films and United States. Office of Education. Division of Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in supervision”
Several workmen are asked what they consider to be the attributes of a good supervisor. The four most important qualities are: always keep promises, never take credit for someone else’s work, don’t pass the buck and don’t play favourites

results.title: Supervising workers on the job
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker, Caravel Films and United States. Office of Education. Division of Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Problems in supervision”
Various kinds of poor supervision practices are shown, among them, nagging, snooping, etc. By dramatised incidents, the poor results of these methods are made apparent and the better ways indicated.
results.creator_credit_for_label: F.E. Brooker, Caravel Films and United States. Office of Education. Division of Visual Aids

results.title: A New supervisor takes a look at his job
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in Supervision”.
A young worker has just been made a line supervisor; in an interview with the superintendent, he is told that in his new job he must learn to get results by working with people instead of with machines.
